column2: A little while later the three white envelopes were jogging sociably along, side by side in a mail-bag, on their way to Louisville.

column2: But their course did not lie together long.

column2: ONE FLEW INTO THE CUCKOO'S NEST.

column2: The letter for Jaynes's Post-office reached the end of its journey first.

column2: It wasn't much of a post-office; only an old case of pigeon-holes set up in one corner of a cross-roads store.

column2: A man riding over from the nearest town twice a week brought the mail-bag on horseback.
column3: A man riding over from the nearest town twice a week brought the mail bag on horseback.

column2: So few letters found their way into this, particular bag that Squire Jaynes, who kept the store and post-office, felt a personal interest in every envelope that passed through his hands.
column3: So few letters found their way into this, particular bag that Squire Jaynes, who kept the store and post office, felt a personal interest in every envelope that passed through his hands.

column2: Miss Elizabeth Lloyd Lewis, he spelled aloud, examining the address through his square-bowed spectacles with a critical squint.

column3: He sat on the counter dangling his big bare feet against a nail keg, and catching flies in his sunburned hands, while he waited for the mail to be opened.

column2: She's that little orphan they're a-bringin' up.

column3: Hump! grunted the squire, slipping the letter into the pigeon hole marked "A." "If that's who it is, I know all about her.

column2: Precious little bringing up she'll get at the Appletons', I can tell you that.

column3: Jake mounted and rode off slowly, his bare feet dangling far below the stirrups.

column3: Afterward she had helped with the breakfast dishes and had taken her turn at the butter making in the spring house, thumping the heavy dasher up and down in the cedar churn until her arms ached.

column3: There was the dinner table to set for the hungry farm hands, and after the dinner was over more dishes to wash. Then there were some towels to iron.

column3: It was two o'clock before her work was all done, and she had time to go up to her little room in the west gable.

column2: The sun poured in through the shutterless windows so fiercely that she did not stay long,--only long enough to put on a clean apron and brush her curly hair, as she stood in front of the little looking-glass.
column3: The sun poured in through the shutterless windows so fiercely that she did not stay long,--only long enough to put on a clean apron and brush her curly hair, as she stood in front of the little looking glass.

column2: It was such a tiny mirror that she could see only a part of her face at a time.
column3: It was such a tiny mirror that she could see only a part of her face at a time.

column2: When her big brown eyes, wistful and questioning as a fawn's, were reflected in it, there was no room for the sensitive little mouth.
column3: When her big brown eyes, wistful and questioning as a fawn's, were reflected in it, there was no room for the sensitive little mouth.

column2: She was free now to do as she pleased until supper-time.
column3: She was free now to do as she pleased until supper time.

column3: Once out of the house, she walked slowly along through the shady orchard, swinging her sunbonnet by the strings.

column3: After the orchard came the long leafy lane, with its double rows of cherry trees, and then the gate at the end, leading into the public highway.

column3: As she slipped her hand around the post to unfasten the chain that held the gate, little bare feet came pattering behind her, and a shrill voice called: "Wait, Betty, wait a minute!"

column3: Betty's little lamb, they called him, and Betty's shadow, and Betty's sticking plaster, because everywhere she went there was Davy just at her heels.

column3: All the Appleton children were boys,--three younger and two older than Davy, whose last birthday cake should have had eight candles if there had been any celebration of the event.

column3: But there never had been a birthday cake with candles on it on the Appleton table.

column3: He was content to follow and ask no questions, for he had learned long ago to look twice before he spoke once.

column3: As he caught up with her at the gate, he did not even ask where she was going, knowing that he would find out in due time if he only followed far enough.

column2: Betty led the way across the road to a plain little wooden church, set back in a grove of cedar-trees. column3: I've never had any girls to play with in all my life, and now there will be two besides Lloyd; and, oh, Davy, best of all, I'll see my beautiful, beautiful godmother!

column2: I shall be there a whole month, and she knew my mamma and was her dearest friend.
column3: I shall be there a whole month, and she knew my mamma and was her dearest friend.

column2: I haven't seen her since I was a baby, when she came to my christening, and of course I can't remember anything about that."
column3: I haven't seen her since I was a baby, when she came to my christening, and of course I can't remember anything about that."

column2: Davy listened to her raptures without saying anything for awhile.
column3: Davy listened to her raptures without saying anything for awhile.

column2: Then he set aside his usual custom and asked a question.
column3: Then he set aside his usual custom and asked a question.

column2: Why are you crying? he demanded.
column3: Why are you crying? he demanded.

column2: There's a tear running down the side of your nose.
column3: There's a tear running down the side of your nose.

column2: Is there? asked Betty, brushing it away with the back of her hand.
column3: Is there? asked Betty, brushing it away with the back of her hand.

column2: I didn't know it.	I didn't know it.
column3: true

column2: Maybe it's because I am so glad.
column3: Maybe it's because I am so glad.

column2: It seems as if I was going back to my own family; to somebody who really belongs to you more than just fourth cousins, you know.
column3: It seems as if I was going back to my own family; to somebody who really belongs to you more than just fourth cousins, you know.

column2: A godmother must be the next best thing to a real mother, you see, Davy, because it's a mother that God gives you to take the place of your own, when she is gone.
column3: A godmother must be the next best thing to a real mother, you see, Davy, because it's a mother that God gives you to take the place of your own, when she is gone.

column2: Oh, let's hurry home and tell Cousin Hetty."
column3: Oh, let's hurry home and tell Cousin Hetty."

column2: Slipping from the window-sill to the floor, she carried the book she had been reading back to its corner in the little red bookcase, and shut it up with the musty volumes inside.
column3: Slipping from the window sill to the floor, she carried the book she had been reading back to its corner in the little red bookcase, and shut it up with the musty volumes inside.

column2: Then she walked slowly down the narrow aisle of the little meeting-house, between its double rows of narrow straight-backed pews.
column3: Then she walked slowly down the narrow aisle of the little meeting house, between its double rows of narrow straight backed pews.

column2: As she reached the bench-like altar, extending in front of the pulpit, she slipped to her knees a moment.
column3: As she reached the bench like altar, extending in front of the pulpit, she slipped to her knees a moment.

column2: Her sunbonnet had fallen back from her tousled curls, and the late afternoon sun streamed across her shining little face.
column3: Her sunbonnet had fallen back from her tousled curls, and the late afternoon sun streamed across her shining little face.

column2: Thank you, God, came in a happy whisper from the depths of a glad little heart.
column3: Thank you, God, came in a happy whisper from the depths of a glad little heart.

column2: It's the nicest surprise you ever sent me, and I'm _so_ much obliged.
column3: It's the nicest surprise you ever sent me, and I'm underscore so underscore much obliged.

column2: Then Betty stood up and put on her sunbonnet.
column3: Then Betty stood up and put on her sunbonnet.

column2: The next moment she had scrambled over the sill, pulled the window down after her, and walked down the slanting board to the ground.
column3: The next moment she had scrambled over the sill, pulled the window down after her, and walked down the slanting board to the ground.

column2: Catching Davy by the hand, and swinging it back and forth as they ran, she went skipping across the road regardless of the dust.
column3: Catching Davy by the hand, and swinging it back and forth as they ran, she went skipping across the road regardless of the dust.

column2: Down the lane they went, between the rows of cherry-trees; across the orchard and up the path.
column3: Down the lane they went, between the rows of cherry trees; across the orchard and up the path.

column2: Somehow the world had never before seemed half so beautiful to Betty as it did now.
column3: Somehow the world had never before seemed half so beautiful to Betty as it did now.

column2: The May skies had never been quite so blue, or the afternoon sunshine so heavenly golden.
column3: The May skies had never been quite so blue, or the afternoon sunshine so heavenly golden.

column2: She sang as she went, swinging Davy's warm little hand in hers.
column3: She sang as she went, swinging Davy's warm little hand in hers.

column2: It was only one of Mother Goose's old melodies, but she sang it as a bird sings, for sheer gladness:
column3: It was only one of Mother Goose's old melodies, but she sang it as a bird sings, for sheer gladness:
